State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology 130th, Road Meilong, District Xuhui Shanghai 200237, People's Republic of China Polyols were used to pretreat the mesoporous silica molecular sieve SBA-16 and thus supported bimetallic Ni-Fe catalyst was prepared in order to address the low activity of CO methanation at lower temperature. The characterization of the pretreated support and catalysts indicated that the residual polyols release heat during combustion, which could provide energy for the decomposition of metal precursors, lowering the decomposition temperature and reducing the metal particle size. More importantly, the pretreatment of support with polyols could increase the isolated silicon hydroxyl, and strengthen the metal-support interaction, thus obtaining smaller metal particles. The smaller metal particles promoted the dissociation of reactant gas, as a result, Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst with polyol-pretreated support could lower the minimum temperature for CO complete conversion from 290 °C to 230 °C while keeping CH4 selectivity above 90%. Catalysts with polyol-pretreated support provide a new possibility for low-temperature CO methanation technology. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polyol Pretreatment Bimetallic catalyst CO methanation Low temperature 1 Introduction CO methanation is an effective way to solve the problem of the direct coal combustion, and Nickel-based catalysts are preferred in CO methanation process due to their low price, good activity and high selectivity to methane. However, CO methanation is a strong exothermic reaction, the system temperature would increase by 74 °C for 1% conversion of CO [1–3], while Ni metal particles are prone to migrate and agglomerate into large particles by Ostwald ripening at a higher temperature, which will result in the decreasing of catalytic activity [4–6]. Therefore, low-temperature CO methanation of Ni-based catalyst has received close attention. One way to lower the CO methanation temperature is introducing a second metal into Ni-based catalysts to form a bimetallic catalyst, such as Fe [7,8], V [9], Co [10,11], Ce [12]. The other way to lower the temperature for CO methanation is to prepare fairly fine Ni nanoparticles catalyst, which is closely related to the concentration, distribution and the nature of hydroxyl groups on the support [13]. According to literatures, there are two different hydroxyl groups on the support, one is hydrogen-bonded hydroxyl (H-bonded Support-OH) and the other is isolated hydroxyl (non-H-bonded Support-OH) [24,25]. During the catalyst preparation process, the metal ions interacting with H-bonded Support-OH would lead to larger metal particle, while those interacting with non-H-bonded Support-OH could result in smaller metal particle [13,14]. That is, eliminating the quantities of H-bonded Support-OH is an efficient way to preparation of fairly fine Ni nanoparticles catalyst. In general, catalysts own a fairly fine Ni nanoparticles based on the support with larger surface area, such as mesoporous silica molecular sieves MCM-41 [15,16], SBA-15 [17,18], SBA-16 [19,20], KIT-6 [4,21,22], among which SBA-16 is preferable for its cage-like pore by which the metal nanoparticles could be better confined. The formation of complex nickel ions by introducing alcohol, alkane and surfactant [17,18,23–25] into impregnation solutions is one way to change the surface groups on the support. For SiO2 supported metal catalysts, the increasing of isolated SiOH on the support SiO2 by pretreated with ethylene glycol would also lead to a highly dispersed catalyst [14,26]. Nevertheless, the mechanism of how the polyols-pretreated support affect the distribution of support surface groups and thus the distribution of metal nanoparticles on support is still not clear. In this study, ethanol, ethylene glycol and glycerol were used to pretreat the support SBA-16 to alter the surface groups, and the metal precursors Ni(NO3)2 and Fe(NO3)3 were co-impregnated with the pretreated support to obtain bimetallic catalyst. The correlation between the structure and performance of the catalyst was characterized by BET, H2-pulse chemisorption, TEM, XRD, H2-TPR, CO-TPD and H2-TPD. FT-IR, XPS and 1H MAS NMR were used to explore the surface groups of pretreated support and TG-DSC was used to analyze the possible weight and heat changes of the pretreated support and that impregnated with metal precursors during the calcination. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalyst Hydrothermal method was used to synthesis mesoporous silica molecular sieve [27–29], in which F127 was the template and TEOS was the silicon source, and the molar ratio of F127: TEOS: H2O: HCl: K2SO4 was 0.0035: 1: 166: 6: 1.5. The process was as follows: 2.5 g F127 and 15 g K2SO4 were dissolved in 150 mL 2 mol/L HCl solution. Then 12 g TEOS was slowly dropped into the mixed solution, after stirred for 24 h at 38 °C, the mixed solution was transferred to a polytetrafluoroethylene reactor, and kept at 100 °C in a homogeneous reactor for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the suspension was filtered, washed, dried and calcined to remove the template, then the mesoporous molecular sieve SBA-16 is obtained. SBA-16 was pretreated by ethanol, ethylene glycol and glycerol by incipient wetness impregnation method, and then dried at 60 °C, 120 °C and 180 °C, respectively, and the pretreated support were obtained. Then Ni(NO3)2•6H2O and Fe(NO3)3•9H2O were co-impregnated with the pretreated support by the same method. After the mixtures were left for 6 h at room temperature and then dried at 60 °C for 8 h in vacuum, the solid powder was calcined at 550 °C in air atmosphere for 5 h, and the bimetallic Ni-Fe catalyst was obtained. The metal loading of Ni is fixed at 10wt.% and Fe is 2wt.%, and the catalyst are named as Ni-Fe/S16, Ni-Fe/S16-E, Ni-Fe/S16-EG, Ni-Fe/S16-G, respectively. 2.2 Characterization of pretreated supports and catalysts The catalyst, along with the pretreated support, was characterized by N2 physical adsorption-desorption, Transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2-pulse chemisorption, H2-programmed temperature reduction (H2-TPR), CO-programmed temperature desorption (CO-TPD), H2-programmed temperature desorption (H2-TPD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Thermogravimetric-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC), 1H MAS NMR spectra. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore width distribution of catalysts were obtained from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm at liquid nitrogen temperature (-196 °C) by Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Before the adsorption-desorption experiment, the samples were degassed under vacuum for 5 h at 250 °C. The specific surface area (SBET) of catalysts was calculated by Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation and the pore volume (VP) was calculated according to the Barett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) equations. The pore width distribution was calculated through density functional theory (DFT). The morphology and metal dispersion of calcined catalyst was intuitively observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) through JEM-2100 microscope at a 200 kV acceleration voltage. Before the experiment, the calcined catalyst was subjected to ultrasonic irradiation in ethanol for 15 min and then the suspension was dispersed on the micro grid copper mesh under the illumination of an infrared lamp. The crystallographic structures were obtained from Bruker advanced D8 powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu Kα (λ=1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Continuous scanning with a scan rate of 10° min−1 within the range of 10–80° was obtained and the results were compared with the JCPDS (Joint Committee on powder Diffraction Standards) PDF cards. Micromeritics Auto Chem II was used to record the reduction properties (H2 temperature-programmed reduction, H2-TPR), metal dispersion (H2 pulse chemisorption), CO desorption curves (CO temperature-programmed desorption, CO-TPD) and H2 desorption curves (H2 temperature-programmed desorption, H2-TPD). Prior to temperature-programmed reactions, 50 mg sample was pretreated at 200 °C in Ar atmosphere for 1 h to remove the impurities. Consequently, for a typical H2-TPR test, sample was cooled down to room temperature and then heated to 900 °C at 10 °C/min in 10 vol% H2/Ar and the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signals record the H2 consumption during the temperature-programmed reduction process. For the CO-TPD and H2-TPD test, the sample was cooled to temperature after the pretreatment, and the gas was changed to 10 vol% CO/Ar (10 vol% H2/Ar) to be adsorbed in catalyst for 1 h, then changed to He for 1 h to remove CO (H2) in physical-adsorbed state. Subsequently, the sample was heated to 900 °C and thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signals was recorded synchronously. For a H2 pulse test, the sample was reduced at 500 °C for 2 h in the reactor, and then the sample was packed into the U-shaped glass tube. Then Ar was purged into the quarters tube to remove the impurities, finally 10 vol% H2/Ar was injected to the tube 10 times until adsorption of H2 was saturated. The dispersion of Ni was calculated based on the H2-pulse chemisorption results using the following equation: D ( % ) = 2 × V a d × M × S F m × P × V m × d r × 100 Where Vad (mL) is the volume of chemisorbed H2 at the standard temperature and pressure (STP) conditions measured in the H2-pulse chemisorption test; M is the molar mass of Ni (58.69 g mol−1); SF is the stoichiometric factor (the Ni:H ratio in the chemisorption, in this conditions, assuming the adsorption stoichiometry of H/Ni = 1:1); m (g) is the sample weight after reduction; P is the weight fraction of Ni in sample; Vm is the molar volume of gas (22.4 L mol−1); d r is the reduction degree of Ni determined by H2-TPR. The surface functional groups were determined by Perkin-Elmer Spectrum GX Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). Few samples were thoroughly ground with KBr for tablet compression, and then dried at an oven to remove adsorbed water. ESCALAB 210Xi X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) instrument with a monochromatized Al Kα radiation (hν=1486.6 eV) was used to detect the surface atom ratio. The data was calibrated by C1s at 284.8 eV. 1H MAS NMR was used to characterize the surface state of H in support and calculate the ratio of isolated SiOH/H-bonded SiOH on the polyols-pretreated support surface. TG-DSC 449 F3 synchronous thermal analysis is used to measure the weight change and heat change that may occur during the calcination process after impregnating polyols- pretreated support with metal precursor. The samples were heated from room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/min to 900 °C, and the thermal weight loss and heat absorption and release during the process were recorded. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The low-temperature CO methanation reaction performance of the catalyst was carried out on a fixed-bed microreactor with an inner diameter of 10 mm. The temperature was detected by a K-type thermocouple located in the gas body near the catalyst. 0.2 g calcined catalyst was packed in the middle of a stainless steel tube, heated to 500 °C at a rate of 20 °C/min under a 20 ml/min N2 atmosphere, and then reduced with 20 ml/min H2 for 2 h. After reduction, the temperature was lowered to 200 °C in N2 atmosphere, and the gas was changed to reactant atmosphere, where H2/CO/N2=3/1/1, WHSV=15,000 mlg−1h−1, after the reaction system was kept stable for 1 h in the range of 200–300 °C, the composition of the product was then analyzed. The reaction outlet gas was cooled down by air for enterprise separation and then introduced to the online gas chromatograph (Techcomp GC7980). The chromatograph was equipped with a plot-Q capillary column hydrogen flame ion detector (FID 1) to detect CnHm compounds in the product, a TDX-01 column-packed thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to detect CO, CH4 and CO2 with high concentration in the product, and a reformer (FID 2) to detect CO, CH4 and CO2 with low concentration. The catalytic activity of the catalyst was presented by the conversion of CO and the selectivity of the product, which were calculated by the following equations: X CO ( % ) = F CO , in − F CO , out F CO , in × 100 S C H 4 ( % ) = F C H 4 , out F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 S C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 , out F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 S C 2 − C 4 ( % ) = ∑ n F C n , out F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 3 Results 3.1 The properties of polyol-pretreated support The pretreated supports and that impregnated with metal precursors are subjected to TG-DSC in air atmosphere to characterize the possible weight and heat change in the calcination process, as shown in Figs. 1 and 2 . For S16, the weight loss before 100 °C is caused by the volatilization of free water absorbed by the porous structure of the support, and that between 100 and 300 °C belongs to the dehydration of the surface H-bonded SiOH, and the loss between 300 and 800 °C is attribute to the condensation of isolated SiOH on the support surface [30]. After pretreated with ethylene glycol and glycerol, a sharp weight loss appears near 300 °C, which is caused by the combustion of polyol remaining on the surface of the support after pretreatment. From the results of thermal weight loss, it can be seen that the final weight of the unpretreated S16 is about 85.5%, and that pretreated with ethanol is about 85.0%, indicating that almost all ethanol is volatilized during the drying process due to its lower boiling point, so the pretreatment with ethanol cannot promote the metal dispersion. The final weight of the ethylene glycol and glycerol-pretreated support is about 74.6% and 69.2%, respectively, which can indicate that polyols remain on the surface of the support after ethylene glycol and glycerol pretreatment for their higher boiling point. In addition, it can be seen from Fig. 1 that there is no obvious endothermic peak in the DSC curve of S16 and there is a small exothermic peak at 441 °C of the DSC curve of ethanol-pretreated support, while the ethylene glycol and glycerol-pretreated supports show strong exothermic peaks at around 300 °C, which are ascribed to the combustion of incompletely volatized polyol. The TG-DSC results of the pretreated supports demonstrate the weak interaction between the alcohols and the surface groups of the support. It can be seen from Fig. 2 that there are also three significant weight loss before 800 °C in the air atmosphere after the unpretreated support is impregnated with the metal precursor. Among which the weight loss before 100 °C belongs to the free water that is not completely volatilized during the drying process or the adsorbed water; the slow weight loss between 100 and 250 ˚C belongs to the bound water in the metal precursor; and the weight loss (5.6%) of about 300 ˚C belongs to the decomposition of metal precursors. From the DSC curves, there are two endothermic peaks around 100 °C and 300 °C after the unpretreated support is impregnated with the metal precursors. Among them, the peak around 100 °C is caused by the volatilization of free water, and the peak around 300 °C is caused by the decomposition of the metal precursor. The endothermic situation of the ethanol-pretreated support impregnating with metal precursor is the same as that with unpretreated support. However, there are obvious differences in the heat change after the support is pretreated with polyols. Apart from the endothermic peak at 100 °C belongs to the volatilization of free water, and the peak at near 200 °C attributes to the loss of bound water and decomposition of the metal precursors (corresponding to the weight loss of 9.4 and 8.4% in catalyst precursors with ethylene glycol and glycerol-pretreated supports, respectively), there appears an exothermic peak at 300 °C ascribed to the combustion of polyols. The decomposition temperature of metal precursor with polyols-pretreated support significantly decreases from about 315 °C to 208 °C. Since the decomposition of metal precursor is endothermic, the heat released by the combustion of polyol can be quickly absorbed by the metal precursors to provide heat for the decomposition of nitrates, thus lowered the decomposition temperature of metal precursors [31,32]. It is known from Farhadi's and Roostaei-Zaniyani's [33,34] works that a lower decomposition temperature of metal precursors could effectively preventing the growth of metal oxide crystallite. In our previous works, the metal particle size and metal dispersion do not change with the calcination temperature below 700 °C [35]. Therefore, the pretreatment of support lowers the decomposition temperature, resulting in smaller metal crystalline grain. To explore how the polyols affect the distribution of the surface Si-OH groups on support, FT-IR spectra, XPS and 1H MAS NMR for the support pretreated with ethanol, ethylene glycol and glycerol are proceeded, and the result is shown in Figs. 3–5. From the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 3), the supports show the typical adsorption bands of SiO2 matrix: the adsorption band at 464 cm−1 belongs to the bending vibration of cyclic Si-O-Si; adsorption band at 800 cm−1 is attribute to symmetry stretching vibration of Si-O in Si-O-Si; adsorption band at 1088 cm−1 is ascribed to the vibration of asymmetry stretching of Si-O from Si-O-Si; the band at 959 cm−1 is corresponding to the -OH stretching vibration from surface Si-OH groups [26,36,37]. The adsorption band at 1640 cm−1 and 3440 cm−1 are ascribed to the bending and stretching vibration of -OH from H2O, respectively. The polyols-pretreated supports show not only the typical adsorption band to SiO2 matrix, but also a band sequence to the presence of polyols. Stretching vibrations attributed to the C-H bond are noticeable in the regions of 1400–1600 cm−1 and 2800–3000 cm−1 [38], which are caused by the –CH2– groups from polyols. Besides, there appears an adsorption band at 878 cm−1 for the polyols-pretreated supports, which is ascribed to the deformation vibration of C–C bond in polyols [39]. The above observations corroborate the interaction between the polyols with the surface SiOH groups of SiO2. The result of surface element distribution calculated from XPS slow scanning is shown in Table 1 , from which we can see that there is carbon species on the support surface, and the glycerol-pretreated support owns the most surface carbon species, which may due to its highest boiling point. Meanwhile, it can be seen from the XPS spectrum of C1s ( Fig. 4) that a carbon species peak appears near the binding energy (BE) of 284.8 eV for all the support, which belongs to exogenous carbon [40,41], and the carbon species with a binding energy of 286.6 eV represents the residual organic carbon species, which may be the template that was not completely removed during the synthesis of molecular sieve [42]. After the support is pretreated with ethylene glycol, C1s showed a peak of carbon species at a binding energy of 287.2 eV. And after pretreatment with glycerol, in addition to 287.2 eV, a peak of carbon species also appears at 289.1 eV, which is attributed to the C–O and C–C in polyols, respectively. The results indicate that a certain amount of polyol remains on the surface of the support after the pretreatment with polyols, which can be verified by the result of the surface atom ratio. However, from the TG results and the surface atom ratio calculated from XPS scanning we can see that the interaction between alcohols and support surface is weak so that most of the alcohols are volatized during the dry process. The XPS results confirms that there exists weak interaction between alcohols and surface groups of the support. 1H MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 5 ) were obtained at 400.1 MHz in single-pulse experiments with a 3 s pulse and a 4 s repetition time and 100 scans, and recorded with samples spun at 8 kHz. The chemical shifts were referenced to H2O. Careful examination reveals that the 1H MAS NMR spectra can be deconvoluted into two components centered at 2.0–3.0 ppm and 3.0–4.0 ppm, respectively. The peak at 2.0–4.0 ppm has previously been assigned to SiOH moieties of silica or silica-like regions of silica-alumina samples. It is well known that hydrogen bonding produces a proton shift to a lower shielding and that the magnitude of the low-shielding shift increases with stronger hydrogen bonding [43,44]. Thus the peak at 3.0–4.0 ppm is assigned to H-bonded SiOH, and the peak at 2.0–3.0 ppm is assigned to isolated (non-H-bonded) SiOH. By integrating the corresponding peak, we calculated the relative proportions of these two kinds of silanol groups on different polyols-pretreated support silica surfaces. From the calculated ratio of SiOH/H-SiOH of pretreated support (Table 1), the proportion of isolated silicon hydroxyl on the surface of the support pretreated with ethylene glycol achieves the highest (the ratio of SiOH/H-bonded SiOH is 3.42), followed by glycerol (2.25), while the pretreatment with ethanol decreases the H-bonded SiOH on the surface of the support slightly. It is found that the proportion of isolated SiOH compared with H-bonded silanols increases with the polyols-pretreated support. 3.2 The properties of the catalysts The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm curves of the support and catalysts with pretreated support and the pore size distribution obtained from the BJH isotherm are shown in Fig. 6 . There is a slightly increase of the adsorbed quantity in the low relative pressure (P/P0) of 0–0.1, means that there exist few micropores. The hysteresis loop appears in the middle relative pressure of 0.4–0.7, indicating the presence of mesoporous in the material. The adsorption saturation is reached at the high relative pressure of 0.7–1.0, indicating that there are no large pores in the material. The curve of S16 is a type IV adsorption isotherm with a H2 hysteresis loop, indicating that the pore structure of the support is like an "ink bottle" with a small mouth and big belly [27,45]. It can also be seen that the type of the curves and hysteresis loops of the catalysts with polyol-pretreated support has not been changed, which means that the pretreatment and loading of metals do not change the structure of the support. From the pore size distribution, the support S16 has a type of small pores at 1–2 nm, and the main pore size distribution is 6–7 nm, which is consistent with the "ink bottle"-like structure. The BET specific surface area, pore volume, main pore size of the support and the catalysts are listed in Table 2 . It is clear that the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst are significantly reduced after supporting metal. Meanwhile, the pore size of the catalyst slightly reduced, indicating that part of metal particles has entered the pores of the support. The specific surface area of the catalyst pretreated with ethylene glycol and glycerol decreased more seriously, indicating that more metal particles entered the pores of the support. Thus, it is deduced that the pretreatment of support with polyols produces more smaller metal particles, which could enter the pore of support easily, and thus decreasing the specific surface area, pore volume and pore width of support. TEM is to record the distribution and the size of the metal nanoparticles on the support (Fig. 7 ). It can be seen that the average particle size with non-pretreated support is 60 nm. After the support is pretreated with ethanol, the average size of particles increases to 80 nm, while that is 6–8 nm in the catalysts with ethylene glycol and glycerol-pretreated support. The result indicates that ethanol-pretreatment of the support does not improve the distribution of metal particles on the support, which might due to the complete volatilization during the dry process for its lower boiling point. The ethylene glycol and glycerol-pretreatment of the support can significantly promote the dispersion of the active metal on the support probably for their partly residual after desiccation due to their higher boiling point. The metal dispersion of catalysts is listed in Table 2, from which we can see that the metal dispersion increases after the support is pretreated with polyols, and reach the highest (6.09%) in the ethylene glycol-pretreated support, followed by glycerol-pretreated support (1.92%), rather higher than that with unpretreated support and ethanol-pretreated support (0.70 and 0.68%), meaning that the polyols-pretreatment of support can significantly promote the metal dispersion. Moreover, the HRTEM and EDS-mapping images of reduced Ni-Fe/S16-EG catalyst were shown in Fig. 8 , from which it can be seen that the distribution of Ni element and Fe element are consistent with Si and O element, and the HRTEM image shows the clear and intersected metallic lattice fringe and the lattice spacing of metal in Ni-2Fe/S16-EG catalyst is ca. 2.03 A, which belongs to Ni (111) or Fe (101) plane according to PDF# 04-0850 and PDF# 50-1275 card. The results indicated that Ni element and Fe element distribute uniformly in the catalyst. The reduction properties of the calcined catalyst are analyzed by H2-TPR, through which can reveal the interaction between the metal particles and the support in the catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . There are two reduction peaks around 330 °C and 520 °C in the Ni-Fe/S16 with unpretreated support. The two reduction peaks at different temperatures also indicate that there are two different metal oxide species on the surface of the support. The peak at lower temperature 330 °C belongs to the reduction of NiO-Fe2O3 with weak interaction with support or free NiO-Fe2O3 [46], while the peak at higher temperature 520 °C belongs to the reduction of the NiO-Fe2O3 with strong interaction with the support [47]. The reduction peak at higher temperature of the Ni-Fe/S16-E catalyst with ethanol-pretreated support shifts to the lower temperature region, indicating that the interaction between the NiO-Fe2O3 particles and support weakens and the metal is getting easier to reduce. However, the Ni-Fe/S16-EG catalyst with ethylene glycol-pretreated support shows only one reduction peak at about 520 °C, which indicates that the interaction between NiO-Fe2O3 particles and the support strengthens. Apart from the high-temperature reduction peak at 520 °C, the Ni-Fe/S16-G catalyst with glycerol-pretreated support shows a small low-temperature reduction peak at 280 °C, which means that there are small parts of metal particles interacting with support weakly. Combined with the TEM results, we have known that the metal particles with ethanol-pretreated support become larger, while the metal particles with polyols-pretreated support become smaller, indicating that the larger metal particles weaken the metal-support interaction and the smaller particles strengthen the metal-support interaction. From the above, it is approved that the polyols-pretreated support leads to strong metal-support interaction. Meanwhile, XRD patterns of the catalysts before and after reaction are shown in Fig. 10 . In the XRD profile of Ni-Fe/S16 before reaction, the broad peak at about 23° is the peak of amorphous SiO2, which belongs to the support SBA-16; the diffraction peaks at 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.9° and 75.4° are attribute to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of NiO according to JCDPS PDF#47-1049, respectively. There are no diffraction peaks belonging to Fe, for that the content of Fe is too low and its diffraction peaks are obscured by Ni and its oxide. The sharp characteristic diffraction peaks of NiO with ethanol-pretreated support indicates that the ethanol pretreatment of the support cannot promote the metal dispersion on the support uniformly and the metal particles are still large. While the diffraction peaks of NiO in the catalyst with ethylene glycol and glycerol-pretreated support have already disappeared, indicating that the pretreatment of the support with ethylene glycol and glycerol could promote the metal particles evenly dispersed on the support, which is consistent with the results of TEM. In the XRD patterns after reaction, according to JCDPS PDF#04-0850, the diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° are attribute to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Ni, respectively. It can be seen that the peak intensity of Ni (111) in the catalyst with ethanol-pretreated support becomes stronger, and a small diffraction peak belonging to Ni (111) of the catalyst with glycerol-pretreated support appears, which means that particle agglomeration occurs during the reduction and reaction process, indicating weak interaction between metal and support. However, the catalyst with ethylene glycol-pretreated support did not show a sharp Ni (111) diffraction peak after reaction, which means that the strong metal-support interaction in the catalyst with ethylene glycol-pretreated support could well inhibit the agglomeration of metal particles during the reduction and reaction, and the results are consistent with the H2-TPR analysis. To sum up, the pretreatment of support with polyols can significantly decrease the metal particle size and strengthen the metal-support interaction to prevent the metal agglomeration. 3.3 The catalytic performance During the CO methanation process, the conversion of CO to CH4 (CO+3H2 =CH4 +H2O) is the main reaction. There are also some side reactions such as the water gas shift (WGS) reaction (CO+H2O=CO2+H2 ), CO disproportionation reaction (2CO =C+CO2 ) and chain growth reaction ( n C O + m + 2 n 2 H 2 → C n H m + n H 2 O ), which affect the CH4 selectivity. At a lower temperature (<300 °C), we have detected no carbon deposition on the catalysts. By calculating the sum of unreacted CO, produced CH4, CnHm and CO2, and the carbon balance during the reaction reached about 99%, and the error is within 1%. The catalytic behaviors of the catalysts in CO methanation is performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 11 . It can be seen that as the temperature increases, the CO conversion of all catalysts show a trend of increasing first and then stabilizing. The 100% CO conversion temperature of Ni-Fe/S16 and Ni-Fe/S16-E catalysts is 290 °C, while the Ni-Fe/S16-EG and Ni-Fe/S16-G catalysts achieve 100% CO conversion at 230 °C, demonstrating that the CO conversion is significantly improved at low temperature. The CH4 selectivity of Ni-Fe/S16-EG and Ni-Fe/S16-G catalysts shows an upward trend with increasing temperature, while that of Ni-Fe/S16 and Ni-Fe/S16-E showed a trend of decreasing first and then increasing, and the C2-C4 products first increase and then decrease with the increase of temperature. Meanwhile, it can be seen that the CH4 selectivity of all catalysts at lower temperature (below 240 °C) is relatively low, but that of Ni-Fe/S16-EG and Ni-Fe/S16-G catalysts is significantly higher than Ni-Fe/S16 and Ni-Fe/S16-E. The CH4 selectivity is above 90% in the catalyst with ethylene glycol-pretreated support when the temperature exceeds 230 °C. At a higher temperature (above 290 °C), the CO conversion rate and CH4 selectivity of the catalyst have little disparity, which is probably due to that the metal supported by the mesoporous molecular sieve offers sufficient active site for CO methanation. It can be concluded that polyols pretreatment of the support can significantly enhance the catalytic activity of CO methanation at low temperature, and the minimum complete CO conversion temperature could be lowered from 290 ˚C to 230 ˚C under the premise of maintaining the CH4 selectivity above 90%. Table 3 shows the recent comparison of catalytic activity for CO methanation when H2/CO=3/1, and seen from the results that the catalyst prepared with polyols-pretreated SBA-16 exhibit superior low-temperature catalytic performance, and the 100% CO conversion temperature reaches 230 °C, the lowest among the supported noble metals catalysts, which means that the pretreatment of support with polyols could significantly improve the catalytic activity for low-temperature CO methanation. The selectivity-conversion plot of the catalyst was provided to compare the CH4 selectivity under the same CO conversion, as shown in Fig. 12 . It was found that the CH4 selectivity of the catalyst at lower CO conversion was greatly improved with polyol-pretreated support, and there was little difference in the CH4 selectivity at 100% CO conversion, which means that the pretreatment of support with polyols can greatly improve the activity of the catalyst at lower temperature, but has little effect on the activity at higher temperature. The turnover frequency of CH4 at 220 °C is calculated and the results are listed in Table 4 . It was found that the amount of generated CH4 (TOF(CH4)) on the per Ni surface of the catalysts with polyol-pretreated support at 220 °C increased by 3–4 times, means that the poly-pretreatment of support greatly improved the catalytic activity at low temperature. At a lower temperature (220 °C), for Ni-Fe/S16 catalyst, the selectivity of C2-C4 reaches up to 43%. This may be due to the fact that the rate-controlling step of the reaction under low temperature condition is not only the dissociation of CO, but also the dissociation of H2, so we perform CO-TPD and H2-TPD analysis on the reduced catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. 13 . It can be seen from the CO-TPD that for the Ni-Fe/S16 catalyst, there are three CO desorption peaks at 100 °C, 250 °C, and 600 °C. The peak at 100 °C represents the desorption of CO from a single-layer chemisorption with low activation energy [53], and the peaks at higher temperature of 250 °C and 600 °C represent the desorption of CO from bridged chemisorption on two sites with higher activation energy [51]. From the H2-TPD results, the catalysts exhibit three H2 desorption peaks at 120 °C, 360 °C and 900 °C, respectively. The peak at about 120 °C is ascribed to the desorption of H2 weakly adsorbed to active metal sites, the peak at 360 °C is the desorption of the strongly adsorbed H2, and the peak at 900 °C belongs to the hydrogen spillover from metal to metal or metal to support [10,54,55]. After the support is pretreated with polyols, the intensity of the CO and H2 desorption peaks at lower temperature increase seriously, indicating that the support pretreatment with polyols promotes adsorption of CO and H2 in the reaction gas, which determines the dissociation of the reaction gas. The CO-TPD and H2-TPD data were further analyzed and the proportion of CO and H2 desorbed near 100 °C was calculated, as shown in Table 5 . From the calculated ratio of H2/CO desorbed near 100 °C, the value of the catalyst with unpretreated support is 4.39/1, much higher than the ratio of H2/CO in the feed gas (3/1), indicating that this catalyst has higher dissociation capacity for H2 than CO. And the value of the catalysts with polyols-pretreated support is close to 3/1. Since the stoichiometry of the main CO methanation (CO+3H2=CH4+H2O) is H2/CO=3/1, the dissociated H2 and CO by the catalysts with polyols-pretreated support is much closer to the stoichiometry of the main reaction. Therefore, the catalyst with polyols-pretreated support has higher selectivity to CH4, which is also corresponding to the above CH4 selectivity-CO conversion plot. In a word, the pretreatment of support with polyols refine the metal particles significantly, promoting the CO and H2 dissociation at low temperature, thereby improving the low-temperature activity of the catalysts. 4 Discussion Scheme 1 shows the diagram of the influence of polyols-pretreatment of support on the surface SiOH groups and the distribution of metal particles. There exists intramolecular hydrogen bond in the support due to the activeness of SiOH, which could form much H-bonded SiOH. When the polyols are introduced in the system, the H in SiOH gets easier to form hydrogen bond with the O atom in polyols. After the polyols are volatized due to the weak interaction with support surface groups after the dry process, the H in SiOH is hard to form intramolecular hydrogen bond due to the steric hindrance, thereby increasing the isolated SiOH. However, there is only one -OH in ethanol, forming one hydrogen bond with SiOH, by which could not affect the intramolecular hydrogen bond, and the residual part increases the H-bonded SiOH. The metal ions preferentially interact with the H-SiOH for the large density of electron cloud. The H and -OH in H-bonded SiOH would be removed by dehydration condensation during calcination easily, forming Si-O-Si bond, which interacts with metal weakly, resulting in metal migration and agglomeration and finally forming large metal particles. Nevertheless, the H in isolated SiOH would be removed through reacting with NO3 − to generate NO2, O2 and H2O [14,56], resulting a strong interaction between the metal and SiO groups, by which can inhibit the agglomeration of metal particles, and finally forming smaller metal particles. In a word, the pretreatment of support with polyols could increase the isolated SiOH by steric hindrance, thus leading to strong metal-support interaction, lowering the decomposition temperature of metal precursor, then obtaining smaller metal particles and promoting the dissociation of reactant gas (CO and H2), ultimately enhancing the catalytic performance. 5 Conclusion In this paper, polyols such as ethylene glycol and glycerol were used to pretreat the mesoporous silica molecular sieve SBA-16 by wet-impregnation method, and bimetallic Ni-Fe catalysts was prepared. Studies have found catalysts with polyols-pretreated support shows excellent catalytic activity in low-temperature CO methanation, and the minimum temperature of CO complete conversion was lowered to 230 °C from 290 °C while keep the CH4 selectivity above 90%. The characterization of the pretreated support indicated that after the support was pretreated by high boiling-point polyols, the remaining polyols on the support surface released heat during combustion, which can provide energy for the decomposition of the metal precursor and lower the decomposition temperature of metal precursor, thereby achieving smaller metal particles. Moreover, the pretreatment of support increased the isolated silicon hydroxyl on the support surface, resulting in strong interaction between metal and Si-O groups and preventing the agglomeration, finally obtaining catalysts with smaller metal particles. The metal particles in catalyst with polyols-pretreated support could be significantly refined from about 60 nm to 8 nm and greatly promoted the dissociation of CO and H2, thus improving the low-temperature CO methanation catalytic performance. The polyol-pretreatment of support could provide a new solution for low-temperature methanation technology. coredata.dc:description: Polyols were used to pretreat the mesoporous silica molecular sieve SBA-16 and thus supported bimetallic Ni-Fe catalyst was prepared in order to address the low activity of CO methanation at lower temperature. The characterization of the pretreated support and catalysts indicated that the residual polyols release heat during combustion, which could provide energy for the decomposition of metal precursors, lowering the decomposition temperature and reducing the metal particle size. More importantly, the pretreatment of support with polyols could increase the isolated silicon hydroxyl, and strengthen the metal-support interaction, thus obtaining smaller metal particles. The smaller metal particles promoted the dissociation of reactant gas, as a result, Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst with polyol-pretreated support could lower the minimum temperature for CO complete conversion from 290 °C to 230 °C while keeping CH4 selectivity above 90%. Catalysts with polyol-pretreated support provide a new possibility for low-temperature CO methanation technology.
coredata.dc:title: Polyol-pretreated SBA-16 supported Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst applied in CO methanation at low temperature
